review.title: Characterizing the Set of Coherent Lower Previsions with a Finite Number of Constraints or Vertices
review.abstract: The standard coherence criterion for lower previsions is expressed using an infinite number of linear constraints. For lower previsions that are essentially defined on some finite set of gambles on a finite possibility space, we present a reformulation of this criterion that only uses a finite number of constraints. Any such lower prevision is coherent if it lies within the convex polytope defined by these constraints. The vertices of this polytope are the extreme coherent lower previsions for the given set of gambles. Our reformulation makes it possible to compute them. We show how this is done and illustrate the procedure and its results.

metadata.title: Characterizing the Set of Coherent Lower Previsions with a Finite Number of Constraints or Vertices

sections.text: The standard coherence criterion for lower previsions is expressed by an infinite number of linear constraints. For lower previsions, which are essentially defined on a finite number of games of chance in a finite scope of possibilities, we present a reformulation of this criterion that uses only a finite number of constraints. Any such lower prevision is coherent if it lies within the convex polyp defined by these constraints. The cornerstones of this polyp are the extremely coherent lower previsions for the given number of games of chance. Our reformulation makes it possible to calculate them. We show how this happens and illustrate the process and its results.

sections.heading: 3 CONSTRAINTS & VERTICES ANALYZED
sections.text: In this section, we present a number of cases - sets of games of chance K - for which we use Definition 9 to generate a sufficient number of coherence constraints and calculate the corresponding extremely coherent lower previsions. Generally, Definition 9 still generates redundant sets of constraints. Therefore, the use of a redundancy removal algorithm is advisable to speed up the Fourier-Motzkin elimination and the enumeration of vertices. As a warm-up exercise and to illustrate some basic ideas, we first consider cases with few - one, two or three - games of chance (§ 3.1), then increase the number of games of chance and focus on combinatorial aspects (§ 3.2 and § 3.3).

sections.heading: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we have derived a harmless coherence criterion (Definition 9) to define coherent lower premises based on an endless number of possibilities. In this definition, this sentence is limited to a subset of a specific standardized class and contains singleton indicators. But we have also shown that both limitations are substantial: the first, because the extension of the entire class is an isomorphism, the second, because Fourier-Motzkin elimination can be applied. In this sense, we have given a very general characterization of the concept of low previsions. Of the combinatorial data we have received, the set of constraints that are still redundant, but the irredundant propositions may be relatively small.
